comment.narrative: Research and development actionsto be launched in line with the newly developed country programme.
Exploring new areas for expanding the CO programme with government cost-sharing. It was also used for promotion of SDG agenda in the country.

As a result, three projects with the government cost-sharing were developed in the area of economic governance and development. The project documents are pending final approval and signature from the government side. Another project in the area of banking sector and IFI partnership development is at the preparation stage. Regarding SDGs roll-out process, the project contributed to knowledge increase of the major government stakeholders, as well as supported integration into national development programs.

description.narrative: Project aims to strengthen water management practices at national and local levels in response to climate change induced water scarcity risks to local farming systems in Turkmenistan.
populated place

activity-description.narrative: At least 4,000 agri-pastoralists of the Nohur mountainous region develop and implement water harvesting and saving techniques (such as slope terracing, small rainwater collection dams, contour and stone bunds, planting pits, tillage, mulching) to improve soil moisture levels

description.narrative: populated place

activity-description.narrative: At least 8,000 farmers implement community-based well and watering point management measures, including sand fixation and introduction of drought resistant traditional grain varieties in the Karakum desert region

description.narrative: capital of a political entity
populated place

activity-description.narrative: At least 20,000 farmers in the Sakarchaga area benefit from improved irrigation services through the introduction of canal level, localized management practice.

description.narrative: 1.1 Water code subsidiary laws and regulations that introduce progressive pricing policies and communal management for local water services are in place and operational. 2.1 Number of community based adaptation solutions implemented at the local level upon project closure. 2.2 % of population with improved water management practices resilient to climate change impacts in the targeted regions. 3.1 Number of associations with improved institutional capacity to deliver water services to target communities. 3.2 % of targeted population with more secure access to water services in the face of climate change where communal management systems adopted.

comment.narrative: 1. Government has made progressive steps towards improving water management systems. It invests heavily in the improvement and upgrade of water infrastructure and looks out for more advanced technologies. However, water policies remain outdated as well as poorly enforced due to underdeveloped regulations and subsidiary legislation. Tools and methods are missing to indentify the most cost-effective adaptation options in the water policies. Water pricing is largely inadequate. 2. Some of the coping mechanisms employed by farmers, agri-pastoralists and pastoralists in the main agro-ecological systems are increasingly strained due to mounting water deficits. A combination of innovative and traditional measures hasn’t been tested to improve water capture, optimize water demand and improve water efficient applications. Over 2,000,000 people live in the target regions with the majority engaged in agriculture, mainly in marginal lands and having very limited access to stable water delivery services. 3. The State continues to play a far-reaching and predominant role in the economy and acts as the main provider in ensuring adequate living standards of the population, with subsidies, price controls and the free provision of utilities underpinning the system. This has been possible largely due to revenues from the hydrocarbons sector. However, it poses large budgetary burden and results in unsustainable and ineffective water delivery services to farmer and pastoralists communities. Self-functioning and maintained services with the direct engagement of communities are not practiced. Despite existence of water user and farmer associations their role and capacities are limited to improve the water management and delivery options.

1. Conduct training at project pilot sites on WUG organizational structure and development 2. Accomplishment of grant projects by established WUGs at pilot sites 3. Terminal evaluation of the project 4. Completion of project closure procedures (reports, asset transfer, etc.)

1. 2 series of 2-day trainings were conducted in each pilot site of project (Nohur, Karakum, sakarchage) on WUG organizational structure and development 2. Grant projects were successfully accomplished by established WUGs at pilot sites (Pilot region Nohur, WUG “Cheshme”: construction of water pipeline with length of 5,250 meters to deliver water from the reservoir in the mountains to Konegummez village –USD 15,000 ; Pilot region Karakum - WUG “Charwa”: Construction of innovative kak with coated geomembrane in the bottom (village Bori, 170 km away in desert) - USD 7,900; Pilot region Karakum - WUG “Tebigat”: Construction of sardop and innovative kak coated with geomembrane in the bottom and covered with specialized film on the top (Bokurdak settlement) – USD 16,270; Pilot region Sakarchaga - WUGs «№1», «№10», «№12», «№13», «№15» (joint grant proposal): Construction of 2,450 meters of water pipe to deliver water to residents of the "Zahmet" Farmers Association for household needs and the purchase of diesel water pumps for the needs of the tenants to supply enough water from the canal for irrigation of agricultural land, as well as establishment of information resource center to strengthening the capacity of established 5 WUGs.
3. Terminal Evaluation of the project was conducted be independent Evaluator. Terminal Evaluation report was submitted in July 2017 4. Final Project Review Report was compiled, Quality assurance for closure stage was completed and approved, Project vehicle was transferred to partner, other project assets are in the process of transfer to the project partner

comment.narrative:
1. Notification rate of new smear positive TB cases / number per year per 100 000 population: baseline for 2008 is 22. 2. Number and percentage of new smear-positive TB patients successfully treated (cured plus completed treatment) among the new smear-positive TB patients registered: baseline for 2008 is 83%.
Baseline source: NTP data based on 2008 smear positive case notifications and WHO estimates (‘Global Tuberculosis Control: Epidemiology, Strategy, Financing’ (WHO Report 2009), adjusted for the population size (the national figures are higher than those used by WHO). Baseline rate includes only civilian sector. Targets are set for civillian and penitentiary sectors.
Data to be available in February 2017.
Operational and financial closure of project
The project was operationally and financially closed

The focus of the project is on promoting energy efficiency (EE) by improving energy management and reducing energy consumption in the residential sector in Turkmenistan. This will lead to a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Direct beneficiaries are families living in 373 apartments in Ashgabat Other beneficiaries: - population of Turkmenistan - Ministry of Construction - Ministry of Communal Services - State Corporation “Turkmengas” - State Corporation “Oil &Gas Construction” - Ashgabat Municipality - State Building De

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

-Reduction of direct GHG emissions from residential sector of Turkmenistan as a result of the project over 20 years, tCO2e. -Natural gas saved annually as a direct result of the project -Co-financing leveraged for investments in energy efficient reconstruction of existing buildings and construction of new energy efficient housing stock (i.e. beyond existing building code requirements)

comment.narrative: -Limited capacity at present to identify and undertake energy efficiency measures throughout national economy. -Lack of legal framework to promote energy efficiency, lack of specific policies and programs to improve energy efficiency, lack of energy performance guidelines for existing buildings, lack of awareness of the potential to save energy. -Architects, engineers and policy-makers have insufficient knowledge and capacities on energy efficiency techniques. -Absence of energy auditors.

1. Revised national codes [SNT] “Building Thermal Engineering” and “Building Climatology” adopted and confirmed in 2016. 2. Analysis of monitoring and assessment of energy consumption in pilot buildings provided. 3. Recommendations and methodologies on energy management developed and presented to interested agencies. 4. At least 30 professionals, trained in the methodology of energy management. 5. Results of energy management published. 6. Renovation of pilot buildings completed and monitoring begun by quarter 2 of 2016. 7. Guidance manual to SNT “Building thermal engineering” developed. 8. Software “Energy passport of building” developed. 9. Catalogue of solutions to prevent thermal bridges in design of building envelopes developed. 10. National Action Plan including Investment plan for increasing energy efficiency in the housing stock developed and presented to the relevant agencies for approval. 11. Agreement with the national partner concluded by the end of the project on continued operation of the website.

1. Revision of National building codes [SNT] “Building Thermal Engineering” and “Building Climatology” is completed. SNT “Building Climatology” is adopted and confirmed on 8 October 2016, SNT “Building Thermal Engineering” is approved by the Ministry of Construction and Architecture and to be registered by the Ministry of Justice. 2. Regular measurement of energy consumption is conducted in 3 pilot retrofits and 3 baseline buildings and analysis of energy savings for 3 pilot retrofits is provided. Regular measurement of energy consumption (energy monitoring) implemented and analysis of energy savings for 3 new pilot building (their construction is completed in 2014 and 2015) are provided. 3. Guidance for planning and performing energy management of residential buildings in Turkmenistan is developed and presented to professionals of the interested agencies – Ministry of Communal Services and State Concern “Turkmengas”. 4. Practical training on implementation of energy management in residential buildings delivered to about 100 local specialists in 5 administrative areas of the country in 2016. 5. Results of energy audits are published. Systems of energy management piloted in Koshi residential area is to be completed in the beginning of 2017, results of the work will be published in 2017. 6. Renovation of three pilot projects for energy efficiency in renovation of existing buildings is completed in May, 2016. Regular measurement of energy consumption is conducted in 3 pilot retrofits. 7. Guidance manual to accompany SNT “Building thermal engineering” is developed and to be approved and published by the Ministry of Architecture and Construction in 2017. 8. Software “Energy passport of building” to assist in building design and energy-related calculations is developed and presented to interested agencies. 9. Catalog of measures to prevent thermal bridges at joints in new buildings is developed and to be presented to interested agencies and published in 2017. 10. Develo

1. Results of energy management published. 2. Final report of monitoring and assessment of energy consumption in pilot buildings completed. 3. Revised national code [SNT] “Building Thermal Engineering” adopted and confirmed in 2017. 4. National Action Plan including Investment plan for increasing energy efficiency in the housing stock developed and presented to the relevant agencies for approval.

1. Energy management system for collection and transmittal of data for energy consumption was developed. 2.Thermostatic controls were installed in 5 residential buildings and boiler house in the Koshi residential complex and automated data collection was arranged through data loggers, which were connected to a central data repository via Ethernet cables. The data were delivered to the Ashgabat heat utility Ashgabatteplo, to provide a basis for optimizing heat energy production and delivery. Results of this experience with the Koshi pilot site, as well as known best practices from other countries, were put into a guidance document on how to plan and implement energy management. 3. Revised national code (SNT) “Building Thermal Engineering” has been technically cleared by the Scientific-Technical Council of the Ministry of Construction and Architecture, and now awaits final approval by the Ministry of Justice. 4. National Action Plan for rational use of energy in the residential building sector was developed be working group and submitted to relevant agencies for approval. The goal of the plan is the resud=ction of annual consumption of energy resources by no less than 0,5% in the residential sector of Turkmenistan.

description.narrative: The proposed UNDPGEF project will reduce greenhouse gas emissions by improving energy management and reducing energy consumption in the residential sector in Turkmenistan
Cofinancing leveraged for investments in energy efficient reconstruction of existing buildings and construction of new energy efficient housing stock ie beyond existing building code requirements

comment.narrative:
The cofinancing by the Government disbursed so far
About US 12300 disbursed for gas meters for 22 demonstration buildings subject to energy audits and 5 demonstration buildings selected for energy management activities
More US 40 million disbursed for almost 270 thousand gas meters for residential buildings in the country
US 38 million for construction of one demonstration building 12story highcomfort building 114 units including energy efficient design of the highcomfort building Construction is completed
US 161 million for construction of second demonstration building 12story highcomfort building 66 units including energy efficient design of the highcomfort building Construction is to be completed in October 2015
US 31 million for construction of one demonstration typical 9story building 54 apartment units Construction is completed
About US 60000 in inkind services of the Turkmen State Building Design Institute for revision of building codes Building Thermal Engineering and Building Climatology
Additional cofinancing committed and disbursed for three demonstration projects for energy efficiency in renovation of existing buildings

description.narrative: Natural gas saved annually as a direct result of the project

comment.narrative: 5 133 thousand m3

Estimated annual natural gas savings of about 322788 m3 per year in 3 new pilot buildings and also about 285400 m3 per year in 3 pilot retrofits
Total estimated natural gas savings of about 608187 m3 per year in 6 pilot buildings

description.narrative: Reduction of direct GHG emissions from residential sector of Turkmenistan as a result of the project over 20 years tCO2e

comment.narrative: 202866 tCO2e by the end of the project

Estimated direct heat energy savings of 1484334 kWhyr from new pilot buildings Estimated avoided CO2 emissions from new buildings over 20year lifetime of almost 12265 tonnes
Estimated direct heat energy savings of 2125588 kWhyr from renovated pilot buildings
Estimated avoided CO2 emissions from renovated buildings over 20year lifetime of more than 10845 tonnes Total estimated avoided CO2 emissions from 6 pilot buildings over 20year lifetime of 23110 tonnes

description.narrative: Energy consumption in new buildings is reduced beyond current requirements
Existence and content of applicable building codes on building energy performance

comment.narrative:
No code on wholebuilding energy performance Existing codes regulate thermal resistance of building elements but not wholebuilding consumption per square meter Resultant wholebuilding energy consumption levels under code compliance therefore vary from building to building
Existing thermal engineering code adopted in 1998 contains two levels of prescriptive thermal envelope requirements Level 1 and Level 2 Buildings consume 3570 percent less energy under Level 2 than under Level 1 but Level 2 is implemented in practice only for elite residential buildings not common building designs for standard housing

New building energy efficiency code on wholebuilding thermal performance and revisions of existing building codes on roofs and roofing residential buildings and building climatology developed and implemented
New code requires heat energy consumption at or beyond Level 2 for all buildings 5 to 10 percent less than Level 2 for elite residential buildings with Level 1 compliance no longer applicable
Introduction of energy passport system in conjunction with adopted new and revised building codes

Building code Roofs and Roofing is approved by Ministry of Justice and ordered by Ministry of Construction and Architecture for immediate use
Guidance manuals accompanying building codes Residential Buildings and Roofs and Roofing are translated into Turkmen and approved by Ministry of Construction and Architecture for the use and printing
A draft of building code Building Thermal Engineering is developed and reviewed by International Consultant and sent to State Design Institute Turkmendovlettaslama for review
Training for calculation of climatic parameters needed for building code Building Climatology has been provided to specialists of National Committee on Hydrometeorology Software for the calculation is installed and adjusted in the Committee
80 percent of climatic parameters needed for building code Building climatology have been calculated by National Committee on Hydrometeorology
Terms of Reference for preparing a guidance manual to accompany building code Building Thermal Engineering is developed
Terms of Reference for developing a software for filling out the energy passport is prepared
Terms of Reference for preparing a catalogue of construction materials to accompany building code Building Thermal Engineering have been prepared
3 Russias standards on energy efficiency are purchased to be included to Turkmenistans register of standards 2 CIS standards on energy efficiency are translated into Turkmen to be included further to Turkmenistans register of standards

description.narrative: Energyefficient design and technologies are incorporated and visually demonstrated in new and reconstructed residential buildings

No demonstration buildings yet built

New pilot buildings designed and constructed with calculated energy consumption 15 percent less than required by code and five percent less than prevailing best practice for highcomfort buildings

Cost estimation completed for one pilot building 12story 66unit with construction in progress and due for completion by October 2015
Energy savings in new pilot building to be completed in October 2015
66unit highcomfort 10 percent compared to baseline
Monitoring of energy consumption in 2 new buildings completed in the end of 2014 is in progress For the 9story building of the U148 series energy savings over the first five months November 2014 March 2015 were measured at 227618 kWh 40 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions relative to a neighboring building identical except for the absence of energyefficiency measures and 65677 kWh 12 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions beyond code requirements for new buildings For the 12story 114unit highcomfort buildings energy savings over the same fivemonth period were measured at 174598 kWh beyond code requirements about 31 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions

Training on energy efficient building reconstruction experience from implementing integrated building design delivered to at least 50 architects andor engineers
Course materials on energy efficient building design and reconstruction developed and delivered to at least 30 students by the end of Q42014

Practical training on implementation of energy audits in residential buildings are delivered to about 100 local specialists in 5 administrative areas of the country in the period of December 2014 May 2015
Training for calculation of climatic parameters needed for building code Building Climatology delivered to 10 specialists of National Committee on Hydrometeorology in February 2015 Software for the calculation is installed and adjusted in the Committee
Bilateral agreement on revising typical programs for students and Letter of Agreement for developing and adding a section Energy Conservation to the typical program of four specialties in Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute signed among UNDPGEF project and clientTurkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute
A draft of revised typical programs for students and drafts of training materials for lectures practical and laboratory studies for the Energy Conservation section are prepared

Terms of Reference for development of guidance for designers to promote energyefficient integrated residential building design is prepared

description.narrative: Turkmengas and other national agencies understand the potential for savings in its housing stock and have the capacity to identify and undertake investments in energy efficiency there
Existence and volume of activity of program run and funded by Turkmengas andor other state agencies on energy efficiency investment in buildings

comment.narrative: No investment program
Short and longterm investment plan for Turkmengas and Ashgabat housing stock developed with EE design andor retrofit carried out in at least 25 buildings by the end of the project

Energy savings potential is calculated for existing building stock in key cities of Turkmenistan Options of measures for energy efficient retrofitting of the stock are prepared Financial assessment and scenarios of investments for energy efficient renovation of the stock have been prepared
A draft of National Plan on rational energy use in residential building sector has been prepared
Working group composed of representatives of ministries and state organizations relevant to the National plan is established and a meeting of the group is conducted
The assessment of energysaving potential for existing buildings will also be used as a basis project profiles for the National Plan on Mitigation and INDC Intended Nationally Determined Contributions on climate change to be presented at the Conference of Parties to UNFCCC in Paris in November 2015

description.narrative:
Number of energy audits
Number of professionals trained

comment.narrative: No audits training

25 energy audits carried out by project 5 planned for 2013 10 each for 2014 and 2015
At least 30 professionals including Turkmengas staff trained

Methodology to conduct energy audits in buildings is finalised and discussed with local stakeholders It will be sent for confirmation to relevant ministries once the provision on implementation of energy audits is completed
A draft of provisions official instructions on implementation of energy audits in residential buildings is developed
22 energy audits are implemented in demo buildings in 9 cities of 5 areas of the country reports and recommendations are prepared
Summary of 22 energy audits for the general public is prepared
About 100 local specialists in 5 administrative areas of the country are practically trained for the methodology to implement energy audits
Gas meters provided by State Corporation Turkmengas are installed in 5 buildings selected as pilots for energy management studies
Regular measurement of energy consumption is being conducted in 3 demonstration retrofits and 3 baseline buildings
Regular measurement of energy consumption energy monitoring is being implemented for two new pilot building their construction is completed in the end of 2014
A draft of structure for energy management system for 5 pilot buildings is prepared Energy audit of the buildings is completed Data on regular energy consumption in the buildings is collected and analyzed

description.narrative: Human rights affairs

comment.narrative: 1.The M&E system is fully operating. 2.Strengthened capacity of at least 10 CSOs; Recommendations for revision of the Law on public associations are presented to Mejlis. 3.At least 100 officials increased their knowledge regarding Turkmenistan’s international obligations in the field of human rights. 4.Quality UPR report prepared and submitted to UN Treaty Body reflecting recommendations of the international expert.

1.The M&E system for NHRAP was developed and submitted to the Working Group of the Inter-agency Committe for approval. 2. Capacity of twenty representatives from 10 local public organizations were strengthened in strategic planning for nonprofit organizations; A comprehensive review of with recommendations of the national law on “Public Associations of Turkmenistan” was conducted. Recommendations for revision of the Law were shared with the CSOs and National Institute of Democracy and Human Rights for further submision to Mejlis. 3. Forty two officials increased their knowledge on Turkmenistan’s recently received recommendations on UNCAT, CERD, ICCPR and CESCR. 4. Draft of the quality UPR report reflecting recommendations of the international expert was prepared, the UPR report is due for submission in February 2018.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy for Sustainable Water Management in Turkmenistan
capital of a political entity
Energy - power generation

Extent of change in energy efficiency (UNDP Integrated Results and Resources Framework indicator 1.5.2) – specifically, consumption of electricity and fossil fuels and associated emissions of CO2 from water management per hectare of irrigated land Consumption of water per hectare of irrigated land Hectares of land protected and/or reclaimed from salinization Implementation of national and sub-national plans for IWRM (UNDP Integrated Results and Resources Framework indicator 2.5.2). State and private investment in new and efficient integrated water management Number of people benefitting from new and improved water management systems

comment.narrative:
9 million GJ/year and approximately 6.9 MtCO2/year from water management, including non-agricultural uses
24 billion m3 per year of water consumption for agriculture 2 million hectares of irrigated land 69 percent of irrigated land is moderately to severely salinized; approximately 200 million hectares are severely salinized Water codex adopted in 2004, but no supporting regulations nor regional/local plans for implementation of IWRM or energy efficiency in the water sector

• Development of Green polygon is well underway to start testing and demonstration of efficient irrigation systems and practices, and with further regular monitoring to be in place in 2017 to define water savings trends and number of salinized land to be reclaimed and rehabilitated. • Assessment completed on potential reduction of GHG as a result of project interventions with clear recommendations and actions to be implemented, • ToR is drafted to undertake a comprehensive audit of diesel-based water pumps • Feasibility study initiated for construction and operation of a 14km water supply pipeline to shut down 41 diesel operated water pumps and provoke GHG reductions.

description.narrative: Support in Improving Accounting and Audit Systems in Turkmenistan. The project is aimed at improving the national accounting system of Turkmenistan in line with international standards.

title.narrative: 2017 Annual Project Progress Report for Accounting project
National Consultant on National Accountants Certifications System
National Consultant to prepare double-entry accounting guidelines
National Consultant to prepare guidelines for the preparation of the financial statements

description.narrative: The project is aimed at improving the national accounting system of Turkmenistan in line with international standards. It contains the following components
capital of a political entity
-# of methodological documents; -# of recommendations adopted;

comment.narrative: -Lack of NFRS methodologies for commercial enterprises; -No National Accountants Certification System;

1.Achieved. The guidelines of the Double-entry accounting developed by the National Consultant and reviewed by the International Consultant. lt will result in a better understanding by private and state commercial enterprises implementation of the new National Financial Reporting Standards and provision of higher quality financial statements in line with international standards to the main users. 2.Achieved. The Draft of the Guidelines for preparation financial statements according to the NFRS for commercial enterprises prepared by the National Consultant and reviewed by the International Consultant. Introduction of the guidelines will result in a better understanding by private and state commercial enterprises implementation of the new National Financial Reporting Standards and provision of higher quality financial statements in line with international standards to the main users. 3.Achieved. The Tax verification guidelines to link tax accounting and financial reporting prepared by the National Consultant and reviewed by the International Consultant. The guidelines are developed to provide principles and recommendations to the users of unified approach. 4.Achieved. The review of the existing accountants training and examination system conducted by the National Consultant and the conclusions were made and shared with the International Consultant. 5.Achieved. On the basis of the conducted review, the Draft Recommendations for establishing the National Accountants Certification System were developed in a very close collaboration with the International Consultant. Then, the recommendations were shared with the representatives of the key governmental institutions and the comments received. Further developments will take place in 2018 in line with the AWP. 6.Achieved. The Draft Action Plan and budget for implementation of recommendations prepared by the International Consultant. The detailed discussion is foreseen in 2018, as per AWP.

description.narrative: The project will support climate resilient livelihoods in agricultural communities in drought-prone areas of Turkmenistan.
capital of a political entity

comment.narrative: 1. Local company for adaptation and vulnerability assessment to be selected and recruited and assessment launched 2. Project National Coordinator to be appointed 3. Inception workshop to be organized and inception report preparation initiated 4. Project staff (Project Manager and Technical Field Assistant) and Project Expert on Water Resources to be recruited and Project Expert on Land Use Management to be advertised 5. Annual Work Plan and Budget for 2017 to be initiated

1. Adaptation and vulnerability assessment by “Tebigy Kuwwat” started 2. Project registration process initiated by State Committee on Environment Protection and Land resources 3. Inception workshop organized and Inception Report drafted 4. Project Staff and Project experts recruited 5. Annual Work Plan for 2017 drafted and discussed by all members of Project Board

1.1. At least eight farmer and/or livestock associations adaptation plans designed and budgeted through the project and linked to collective community based actions on water savings and efficiency improvements as well as soil fertility and moisture improvements as follows: (i) four adaptation plans by MTR; and (ii) eight adaptation plans by end of project. 1.2. At least 3,000 (or 30%) of targeted agricultural farmers and pastoralists (30% of which are women) reporting improved production of major crops and natural pasture. 1.3. At least 50% of the households supported through alternative climate-resilient livelihood opportunities reporting an increase of >15% of real net household farm income, of which at least 20% are women-headed households 2. 1: At least 3,000 (30% women) of agricultural and pastoral farmers and 100 government staff (20 % women) are trained in on-the-ground application of climate adaptation-related technologies as follows: (i) 1,000 farmers (30% women) and 50 government staff (20% women) by MTR; and (ii) 3,000 farmers (30% women) and 100 government staff (20% women) by end of project 2.2: A package of amendments to the legislation with economic instruments and support for water delivery and local level decision making under increased communal control (refer Output 2.4 for details of proposed legislative measures) 2.3: At least two sector plans (agriculture and water) integrate climate adaptation considerations and budgetary allocations
3.1 National monitoring, reporting and verification system to measure changes in vulnerabilities from adaptation actions with functional procedures and rules in place. 3.2 Five agro-ecological zones in the country models developed that integrate impacts, costs and adaptation actions.

1.1 NO adaptation plans were designed during this year. This work was initiated through organization of the introductory meetings, workshop and training in order to raise awareness of local people about climate change and adaptation to its consequences. 1.2 None of the agricultural farmers and pastoralists is reporting about improved production. The main reason is that project activities carried out during 2017 will show effect on improved production of major crops and natural pasture only next year. During 2017 project implemented the following activities: - 5 water-regulating units - 6 water-measuring units Chopoletti - 20 ground water monitoring wells - Mechanical cleaning of 5 km irrigation canal in Parahat, Lebap province - Mechanical cleaning of 30 km drainage collector in Yagtylyk and Garagum, Dashouz province - Procurement of 2 Laser equipment 1.30 % of the households are supported. Project will undertake certain measures to archive this target through grant allocation which will start from the next year. 2.1 Approximately 354 (32% women) of agricultural and pastoral farmers and 70 government staff are trained. 2.2. Land Resources Inventory Law has been prepared and discussed. On 25 November this Law has been agreed by Mejlis of Turkmenistan. The new version of the Land Code is under preparation and will be submitted to the Mejlis next year. 2.3No sector plans have been developed and integrates climate adaptation considerations.
This work will be implemented next year through the design of Inter-farm water-use planning for each farm association. 3.1 Not achived. 3.2 This activity partly started this year. All necessary information and detailed data on project sites have been collected. Preparation of detailed clusterization has been started by the International Consultant and the results will be achieved next year.

National Consultant to improve a state civil service system of Turkmenistan
Support to the Civil Service A

description.narrative: Under the current project, UNDP plans to provide assistance in development of the strategic visioning and development plans of the Academy, updating existing/developing new curricula for the Civil Service Academy (CSA).
capital of a political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

comment.narrative:
1.Achieved: Prepared preliminary information regarding the Mission & Vision and the development strategy of the Academy. Priorities of the Academy were defined by international consultants and the CSA representatives. This information was disseminated between the teaching academy staff and increased their awareness of Mission, Vision and the 3-year development strategy of the Academy.
2.Achieved: New Curricula was prepared in accordance with the recommendations made by the international consultants. It will be sent to Cabinet of Ministers for further consideration.
3.Achieved: Memorandum of cooperation drafted and sent to Government.
4.Partially Achieved: Main layout is prepared by the EU. Content is being prepared by UNDP.
